Erik Mattsson wrote:

> Somehow I always litter my code with singletons, and its a very easy way
> of handling control in a large application, but this will always have 
> problems
> when testing. (singleton in an OO-environment feels like coding C in C++)

Repeat after me: "Singletons are just fancy global variables."

> Now, when I have a few singletons I try to Mock them. (replace them with
> a fake class, instead of the real class). I have no clue how to do it 
> nice, but heres
> what I do. I would happily take pointer on what to improve!!

First Google "Use your singletons wisely".

Next, I think your approach works well. I would suggest -- if you can -- 
  the following general strategy.

1. Write enough tests to be confident in the required system behavior.
2. Refactor the system to remove the singletons.

That will remove the need for your Mock Singletons. Channel the pain of 
using a mock singleton into the desire to improve the design.

Best of luck, and I hope the article helps.
